We went over to Bedfont Lakes for our 11th different parkrun. Joey and Uncle Michael came over as well. Daddy took Ben and Joey around. Joey smashed his PB and Ben was just 7 seconds out, despite the course being 5.1km long! We stopped by afterwards for a play on the swings and a game of 40 / 40.

We all then trudged over to Camberley to get bank statements for the impending mortgage application and to get Ben some new trainers which he was very proud of.

Daddy continued working on moving stuff from the old shed to the new. He managed to smash a window when the wardrobe fell apart in front of him.

Later in the afternoon, Ben went off to Theo's party over at TriLakes, Yateley. He came back very sweaty.

Us girls stayed in and watched the semi finals of Britain's Got Talent.

title.value: Bedfont Lakes, Camberley, Theo Party, More Sleepovers

info.content:
I think we broke all records for sleepovers this week.

  • Saturday - Joey and Lily at ours.
  • Sunday - Joey and Lily at ours.
  • Tuesday - Ben and Jess at the Elders. Katie at Natasha's
  • Thursday - Katie at Summer Teale's
  • Friday - Katie at Nina's, Jasper at ours, Jessica at Jemima's

Kids.... huh... treat the place like a hotel!

The famous five went to London on this rainy day. Funnily enough we were going to do the Fire Of London walk. We did the usual Gunnersbury thing and tubed it to St Paul's Cathedral. Then the usual Mummy guiding us in roughly the right direction, past Bank, Monument, saw Tower Bridge, and Tower of London. We had a good time together as ever. Kids are mad.

Once the 2 mile trek finished, we decided to head for the Science Museum. With it being a bank holiday and raining, needless to say It was packed. We split. Daddy went with Ben and Jessica in to the Launch Zone which had apparatus to show some basic principals in physics. We did electrical circuits and forces mainly. Jess and Ben were engaged which was good.

Tower Bridge

Tower Of London, with inmates

title.value: Walk 60: Great Fire Of London Walk

info.content: Toby has come out of hospital. Finally the whole Elder crew is re-united. We had a BBQ to celebrate.

Unfortunately Toby was kept in over night, so Daddy took Joey and Lily after he did the Alice Holt Parkrun.

The gang went to the Arena swimming for a couple of hours. The mats were out so Daddy was spinning us around. Other unknown children were coming over to Daddy to get spun as well.

We all slept in the front room and watch films and ate sweets!

New fashion - shoe covers

Again Daddy, Farmor and Farfar worked in the back garden. It was under a week until the shed arrives so final adjustments on the shed base were made.

After Sunday lunch, we all went out for another walk. This time we went over to New Haw and picked up the River Wey, the navigable one and the natural one! Us children took our bikes which was a little disastrous as Jessica fell off quite early and Ben failed to balance properly whilst waiting for a car to pass and fell into a bush of stinging nettles! Anyway it was such nice weather.

The lock where the River Wey meets the River Wey

title.value: Walk 59: River Wey, New Haw Walk

info.content:
Daddy and Ben went off to do their 10th different parkrun this morning. This time Crane Park, Hounslow. A small-ish parkrun. We were first to arrive. Ben started off at a quick pace. Really thought we were on for a PB. However, we misjudged the run a bit. The course was one and a half laps, instead of a normal two. So when we rounded a corner by the finish line we had enough in the tank for another kilometre. Still it was Ben's second best time ever. We were both very happy with this.

They returned home and Daddy's next task was to get ready for a bit of Daddy and daughter time. They both wanted to do a bit of kayaking. The River Abbey was a perfect choice. A circular route, yes even on a river, it had plenty of interesting things to see and challenges to tackle.

They started at Chertsey Bridge and Daddy couldn't quite remember where the entrance to the River Abbey was so they went up and down the Thames a bit passing the same heron three times. It was near the weir which was a bit scary to pass as the waves pushed us into a moored boat. It was a bit dicey for a few seconds, but they powered themselves through and it quickly became all serene. The next task was the tackle the slope by Abbey Chase house. We got out and hauled the kayak up the rollers. We now were officially on the Abbey River. Probably the only craft that's been from end to end for months. The river was banked by lots of vegetation, a lot of it overgrown. Many lilies and bamboo type plants. There were a number of blockages on the route which they had to negotiate. Then there were the low bridges which they had to duck under and the fallen trees. Some were just about passable, one they had to climb onto, use their feet to move the kayak under and then get back in again. All good fun and made it different to a normal boating excursion.

It was a really nice trip. They saw so many nice things together. Their bottoms were getting sore once they had retuned back onto the Thames at Penton Hook, so they stopped off at Laleham for a spot of food and drink. They returned via Chertsey Lock to Chertsey bridge, the car, then home.

Alone

Tree Down

In the afternoon Jessica went to a birthday party in the Methodist church, whilst Mummy and Ben went to the cubs AGM at the cub hut.

title.value: Crane Park PR, Abbey River Kayak. Jessa Party, Cubs Agm

info.content:
We left the boys in the morning as we went to St. Nicholas church for morning service. After lunch we went to ride Tiki. It was the first time that Ben had ridden a horse. He said Tiki went a bit fast for him at times.

Meanwhile Daddy and Pop Pop went to Greenhithe to complete one of the Windsor to Gravesend sections. This was planned to be the final stretch: Greenhithe to Gravesend. The last time Daddy was at Greenhithe Daddy was soaked have rolled the kayak at the QE2 bridge! Could today fair better?

The boys started from the causeway by the Pier Hotel. The weather was overcast and windy. They set off in Pop Pop's kayak and it soon became apparent that the wind was going to play a major part in proceedings. Along with the high tide there was no problem in moving towards the Gravesend direction, more the fact the wind was pushing them into the middle of the river. The boys had to work hard to keep out of the middle especially as there was an oil tanker being pushed by 2 or 3 tug boats. Fortunately they were a way off that. Pop Pop said that when there are 'white horses' on the tops of the waves then it is at least a force 5, which 30 to 35mph winds in English money.

The waves were hitting the boat which was fun at first, but they were taking on water. Some big waves hit them and the craft became more unstable. The boys were paddling almost solely on one side just to keep them from drifting in to the centre. Suddenly another wave crashed in and the boys had to break from paddling just to concentrate on balancing the vessel. A second wave hit them and they almost rolled.

It was at this point the boys, like politicians, very diplomatically suggested that they should moor up by the bank. They had only been going for 20 minutes or so and had almost reached the peninsula at Greenhithe. They paddled hard to the bank and were suprised to see how much water they had taken on board.

Both agreed that it was too dangerous to continue, it would only be a matter of time before they would have rolled the kayak.

Picture paints a 1000 words

Where were they? Well a disused cement works, seemingly miles from anywhere. No life around. The boys split up and headed in opposite directions to find how they could get out of this mess. Eventually they found Ingress Park, so had to carry the kayak back to a mile or so which was quite tiring. They hopped in the car and went back home for a well earned cup of tea!

Daddy ran the parkrun on his own today and did it in a reasonable time. After lunch we were over to Istead Rise, stopping off in Leatherhead on the way to do the River Mole walk. The walk took us from the town centre out in to meadows. The river was pretty shallow. No good for kayaking.

We got to Ma Ma and Pop Pops. We were introduced to the Friends, the US sitcom. Oh no thought mummy and daddy. Hope we are not going to get 10 years worth of that again!

In the evening Daddy went with Ma Ma and Pop Pop, Uncle Richard and Sue to a quiz night in St Nicholas church. It's been 10 years since Daddy last went here.

River Mole

title.value: Walk 58: River Mole, Ma Ma and Pop Pops

info.content:
Bank Holiday Monday and another sunny day. In the morning we caught up on homework and more SATs practice for Katie, who has noticeably been benefiting from all this additional work. This does mean we are continuing with this additional work which is bad from a 10 year olds perspective, but she is making the effort and doing everything we are asking of her.

In the afternoon we embarked on Walk number 57. Chillworth and its mills and hills. There were streams to paddle, bridges to balance across, derelict building to explore, pill boxes, steep, high banks to climb, style to cross and lovely hill top scenary to appreciate. This followed the normal format of initial resistance, followed by begrudging acceptance of having a good time, then tiredness near the end. Ben and Jessica especially played so nicely together. They were playing Army for most of it. General Ben and Captain Jess both gunning there way across the paths. Earlier in the day Katie and Ben had made a CD for the car which meant the whole car had a good sing song on the way home.

Runners and Riders

Jessica U E Gay

The Bridge

The girls went to church in the morning as usual, leaving the boys to go sourcing ingredients for Ben's, Come Dine With Me final. Ben was so desperate to win it, as he wanted the prize money to fund buying Minecraft on the PC. So his idea was a New York themed meal. Bagels for starters, Cheeseburger and Fries for main and a New York Taxi inspired lemon drizzle with a sponge Empire State building. He was very good in the kitchen for a boy who has not shown a lot of interest in cooking before. He shoved Daddy aside when there were tasks he could do. Bagels is something no one had made before. Wierd that you had to dunk in the bread dough into simmering water for a minute. They went down a storm, if a little big. The cheeseburger was hand made from the mince which was nice, but the boys forgot one of the main components of a burger, the buns! Doh. Never mind, the pudding was an interesting combo of a lemon drizzle cake with a slab of yellow dyed icing shaped and carved into a New York taxi. The thought was there. The Empire State building sponge cake, was not handled with particular care in the preparation stage, so end up more like the World Trade Centre towers! Never mind, the boys has spent 3 or 4 hours in preparing for the meal which was reflected in the marks given.

So as the final host, Ben added the scores and anounced that Daddy came 5th, then Mummy, Katie and Jessica all came joint second, leaving Ben as the winner by a single point. He celebrated and shouted winner. It was only 10 minutes later when discussing who gave what marks, that Jessica had given a 6 out of 10, not the nine that Ben had read! Jessica was seeking revenge as she had not forgotten that Ben gave her 1 out of 10 last year! So really Ben came 4th and there was a three way joint winners. However, everyone had accepted Ben as the winner of the prize and got on with it which was nice.

There was a break in the middle of the afternoon. Daddy had treated Farmor et el to a Frenchies, the new Ice Cream Parlour in Camberley, themed like a 1950's American Diner. It was nice that Auntie Susan also came along. Ben had the Blue Moon ice cream, whilst Katie and Jessica had a raspberry and lemon cone with bubblegum balls and marshmellows. Daddy was wincing at the amount of sugar being consumed by all!

Ben's Blue Moon

Lemon and Raspberry, with bubblegum balls and marshmellows

Frenchies Diner

Bens Come Dine With Me Effort

title.value: Frenchies, Come Dine With Me Ben and Resuts

info.content:
It was Rushmoor's inaugrial parkrun and it so happened to co-inside for Frimley Lodge closing for the Surrey Heath show. Over 400 turned up (a parkrun record). It was sunny and all the usual suspects turned up. Even the girls came along to watch and cheer us on. Uncle Michael came 8th with Daddy and Benny coming in at the mid 26 minute mark. It was ran around the polo fields, despite all that space, there were still some bottlenecks.

We dashed straight from there down to Winton to see Charlotte's current residence. She shares a rented house with her friend and her husband. We met Loz for the first time as well. After Daddy had a shower we went to Boscombe Beach and chilled for a bit. We played on the rocks and had a little paddle. After our picnic we travelled to Ringwood and the excellent Moors Valley Country Park. There were loads of different play equipment to go on a tree top walk. We ended with an ice cream and saying goodbye to Auntie Charlotte and Loz.

In the evening we went over to Chertsey Town Football Club as Daddy was involved in the supporters v First XI match. The First XI were short on numbers so Daddy represented them. He came on from the subs bench after 20 minutes and did well playing as a three at the back. He was the centre half general! We got a bit bored in the second half so sloped off home and left Daddy with the Fars. A good, long day

The Lineup

Paddling

Rocks

title.value: Rushmoor Parkrun, Charlotte Bournemouth, Daddy Chertsey Football

info.content:
We all went to church and left Daddy with the Fars working in the back garden. The boys are still sorting out the base for the shed that arrives later next month.

After lunch, Ben with the cubs and Mummy went to St Michael's church in Camberley for the St George's Day parade. Meanwhile, Daddy, Katie and Jessa went swimming at the Arena. Daddy just sat at the edge of the pool as he wasn't feeling too well. the girls played with the Dive sticks pretty much for the whole time.

title.value: More Garden Work, Swimming, St George's Day Parade

info.content:
Daddy was all alone in this week's parkrun as Ben had Yuraj's birthday party to go to, which he was very excited about. It was a laser quest party, and he and his mates had been discussing strategies for the past week or so.

The rest of us were at Farmor's brunch in the morning.

We had a bit of a disaster in the afternoon with the bike rack, which ultimately meant we didn't go for one of our walks!

Ben has moved on to the next craze, which is the Minecraft computer game. The boy is addicted!

The table of food

title.value: Yuraj Birthday and Farmor Birthday Brunch

info.content: Katie went to a lot of effort for her Come Dine With Me. She really want to win obviously.
Daddy met with some old work friends; Michael and Stuart in the Crooked Billet near Hook. Very nice to catch up.
Daddy got a free ticket and went to watch Reading v Middlesborough at the Mad Stadt with Fat Phil.

We met for the Sanders at Shalford Mill, a small National Trust place, but did do an egg hunt, which is now a traditional annual event for us. It took us less than 30 mins to go around the mill to find all the clues and collect our eggs. Having finished early we went for a walk in to the lovely bluebell carpeted woods nearby.

Bluebells in woods in Shalford with the Sanders

For the rest of the day we chilled, prepared for school and Katie continued to work hard in practice Maths questions for her impending Sats.

title.value: Shalford Mill Egg Hunt with Sanders

info.content:
After an early church service we travelled to Alton for an Elder Sunday roast. As ever the crackling on the pork was top dollar. We played on the Xbox, Just Dance game which was a lot of fun.

We then all dashed over to Uncle Pete's for his traditional gathering and general madness. Unfortunately the weather had turned bad today, so we were unable to do the egg hunt in the back garden. We had fun playing upstairs mainly with Barbie's and Playstation 2.

title.value: Easter - Elders Lunch, Peter's Egg Hunt

info.content:
In the morning Ben and Daddy went to pick Max up from his mum's and drove up to Bushy Park, the home of parkrun. We met with Unc Michael and Joey who ran with Ben. It was a nice flat, gravelly track with over 1100 runners! There were even 3 massage tables there as well. Daddy managed to get his year's best time at 23:30-ish, the rest of us got quick times in the 26 minute region. Joey smashed his PB by 3 minutes!

We didn't hang about as we went around to the Stoddart's for lunch and an Easter Egg hunt. We left dad at home replacing the fence panels which had blown down months ago. There has been such a demand for fence panels, that daddy only yesterday got some, and that was by luck.

Daddy was buoyed by his running performance he went out for another few miles along the canal and into Deepcut, whilst the rest of us watched a very entertaining Britain's Got Talent or as Jessica calls it, 'Scots Got Brilliant Talent'.

We left Daddy at stupid o'clock and drove to Gatwick to welcome Ma Ma and Pop Pop back from their Jamaica holiday. They brought us back some lovely t-shirts.

Meanwhile Daddy was busy cooking the gammon and pork on the BBQ. The Fars, Uncle Graham and Auntie Susan came around the house for the first time as a couple. We sat outside all 9 of us and had a good old roast, BBQ style.

After we played some games and chilled in the conservatory. I think everyone was filled. Even the mighty Farfar couldn't finish his lunch!

Susan and Jess enjoying a joke

title.value: Ma Ma Airport Pickup - Gays Good Friday Lunch

info.content:
A bit weird with just the three of us waking in the house. We were constantly in 'text' contact with Katie as she had mummy's phone.

Daddy got up early, borrowed the Fars car and met with Nick, Michael and Steve for a 30 mile bike ride around Hook, Odiham type area. The weather was glorious, so had a nice leisurely trundle around.

In the afternoon we chilled a bit. Daddy carried on the garden clear up. There is a lot of work to be done to get that into shape. We did manage to slope off to the park and fly the aeroplane and watch some park football.

After putting Jessica to bed, the three of us embarked on a game of monopoly. This game went true to form. Mummy, lording it about, letting everyone know she was winning, but overspent and went out first. Ben being ultra picky on the rules got upset when Daddy charged him for landing on his property. Ben reluctantly paid but went into a big huff. So Daddy gave him the money back to keep the peace, but then got in a huff, because Ben did not play in the spirit of the game and for him getting in a huff. Why do we play these games? We all ended of good terms. A busy weekend.

Rockets Are Go

title.value: Park, Jessica pickup, 30 mile Bike Ride, Gardening

info.content:
First up was a Family Parkrun at Frimley Lodge Park. There were 6 Gay's in total competing. Daddy was able to give it full beans, but still came in well short (23:51) of his PB. Ben shepherded Katie around, but gashed his knee open when he waved at Farmor and ran into Katie! They still came in around the 31 minute mark. Mummy and Jessica both completed one lap, as did Farfar who came in 30 seconds better than his previous week's time!

Katie went with an old school friend Leah Sumner and he Dad and sister to their Auntie's flat in Lee On The Solent, near Fareham for a few days. It was sad to see her leave, and Daddy played the Beatles track, She's Leaving Home. Katie was raring to go. It's good to get away for the parents sometimes. We know she'll be a good girl as well.

Making things worse, Jessica decided she was going to her first night away from any family and went to Rainbow camp near Tilford. The three of us took her there and made sure she settled in OK. Of course, she was of a similar disposition, and was raring for mummy and daddy to go and could not wait for her adventure. She was there with her good friend Jermima. They had a great time making lots of craft, running about and playing.

This just left Mummy, Daddy and Ben. As we were reasonably close and the weather was glorious, we decided to go for another walk out of the book. This time Thursley Bog. A place we've never been close to before. It was lovely with the first mile or so on board-walks around the bog. It was only a 2 miler, so we didn't feel too bad taking a hobbling Ben around.

From here, we headed via the scenic route down to Alton where we spent the evening watch the TV and having a nice spot of dinner. We enjoyed the new front room with it's fire and comfy chairs. Lovely.

Thursley Bog

Jess and Jemima

title.value: Walk 56: Thursley Bog, Family Parkrun, Katie to holiday to Lee On The Solent, Jessica Rainbow Camp, and Elders Dinner

info.content:
Jessica's turn for Come Dine With Me. We all had to dress in red of some sort. We had a Spag Bol for starter, Pizza for main and a Diabetics dream for pudding!

Come Dine With Me, Jessica Styley

In the morning the Fars came around to help Daddy do work in the garden. Currently the boys are making a shed base and Farmor was tidying the borders. There is a lot of work to do, but things are moving the right direction.

The rest of us went to church as usual. After a snacky lunch, we headed off to Compton and the Watts Gallery where we started another walk out of the Surrey Kiddiwalk guide. This was a 4 miler, which pleased us kiddies. The usual lethargy wore off after 20 minutes and we had some nice family time. It is really nice to just have time together, a chance to catch up on how everyone is. We passed many walkers along the way. I guess they were ticking off the well trodden North Downs way off their lists.

Family shot at the Loseley Lake

Katie and Ben enjoying a chat

Ben in front of Loseley House

Daddy and Ben went to Frimley Lodge today to run and celebrate James' 100th Parkrun. Well he says 100, officially it's 101st, unofficially it's 99. So take your pick. Anyway, good to see him reach the milestone. Hopefully he'll get his jacket.

It was Katie's turn to host Grace, Natasha and Nina for a sleepover. The 'fun' began at 4pm, when we all sat down to watch the Grand National together. We had a sweepstake which made us scream at the TV for our horses to win.

Daddy took us all to the park, where we played on the swings and flew a toy aeroplane which provided much entertainment, especially for Ben and Jessica. Daddy got it stuck up in the tree, 30 foot up which provided much amusement and members of the public to help get it down!

We headed off to the chip shop for dinner and us children had 4 film lined up: Frozen, The Smurfs 2, Monsters High 13 Wishes and some other Monsters Inc. related film. Ben became an honorary girls for the night. They stayed up till 2:30am!!

We are very proud of Katie. She is such a lovely girl.

Nina, Natasha, Grace, Katie, Ben and Jess

Ben won his school class reading challenge which entailed reading the most books in half a term out of his class. He read about 11 books. He won lots of Beast Quest stuff, like badges, pens and bookmarks. Well done Ben.

He also won Star Of Week on Mrs Good's final day of her career. He won it for being 'An independent thinker and a brilliant problem solver'. Excellent.

title.value: Ben Wins School Reading Challenge And Star Of The Week

info.content: As soon as we awoke we had early breakfast. I had Coco Pops and three pieces of toast. Next we met with the year group and went to see all the animals on site. There were goats, rams, lambs, pigs, ponies which looked like a goat. They had mini-horns on their head. After lunch, we packed our bags then got on the coach homeward bound. We stopped off a Maiden Castle, an iron age hill fort. We went to the very, very top of it. We kept thinking we were at the top, when we got there we found another step in the terrace. We then went back on the coach back to school where Mummy was excited to see me. We arrived 47 minutes late.

In the morning I did Living History. A person dressed up as a Roman solider and took us in a Roman-British house. I also made butter and bread flour. For lunch I had the same as yesterday. In the afternoon we did Den building which was my favourite activity over the whole trip. There were already some sticks there which me and my room mates used to build one big den. After we draped army netting over our den to make it blend into it's surroundings. We then had a bit of a play time before going to the Pirate Party. This was a disco where everyone turned up. We had a bit of a boogie and played a couple of games. One was flip the coin, the other a dance competition. We went to bed about 10pm.

Ben went off last Monday for two nights away with the school to New Barn, near Dorchester. We at home have missed him loads.

Account from Ben. When I got there, the first thing I did was go to my room which was opposite Katie's when she came here. The people in my room were Yuraj, Kai, Sandjog, Reece and Jimonez. We quickly dropped off our bags and went to have our lunch. My lunch consisted of: white bread with no butter on, chocolate spread, salt and vinegar crisps, Penguin biscuit and Apple Juice.

Next, I went orienteering. My partner was Yuraj. There were 10 points to find, each had two letters on to memorize and report back. We were the second to finish out of the whole year of boys. Next we worked on our diary. It said lots of things about our activities. After that, we went to do pottery. I made a clay dog. Last on Monday, the staff at New Barn read us a story. It was a Danish story which had a ghost, a King and poisoning and murder in it. It was a ghoulish story.

Yesterday we left Mummy at home to get on with her essay for play-school, whilst the rest of us headed off to Farnborough to get some bits for Mothers Day

Mummy was treated to croissants in bed (well croissants were on a plate), a couple of Lee Child's books, mint chocolates, liquorice comfits, nuts and some lovely cards.

Daddy went off to meet with his mummy, whilst we went to church and made some posses of flowers for the mothers in the church service.

In the afternoon we met with the Barnett's at Mytchett Canal centre.

A gaggle of mothers

Riding through the woods

Here is Ben's Poem entry

My library is the place to be

There are so many books to see

I've told all my mates

The books are great!

My library is the place to be

My library is the place to be

It is a world of fantasy

Superheroes fly

And villains spy

My library is the place to be

My library is the place to be

Nobody ever disturbs me

If I sit all day

As the hours tick away

My library is the place to be

By Ben Gay (Aged 8)

Ben entered his poem into the library poem competition. It had to be about his library.

Ben's Poem Displayed at Frimley Green Library

Daddy and Ben went off to do our home park run. The Elders came over, so Uncle Michael paced Ben around to his second best time ever. Funnily enough they were both slightly disappointed with the result, as they were hoping to get close to Ben's PB. After a play with Joey and Lily for a bit and bacon rolls all round, the Elders left and we went over to Chobham for another walk out of the book.

This time it was Chobham Common. Funny, as Daddy has lived here for a long time, he's not done that bit of the common before. We all had a good run around and blew away the cobwebs.

Chobham Common Memorial

Ben and Michael finishing Parkrun

In the morning the Fars came over to help Daddy continue with the shed base preparations.

In the afternoon we went over to the Elders and had a play.

We got up early for another Parkrun tourist trip, this time to Hampstead Heath. Max had invited another old school friend along, Nicholai, from Copenhagen. It was good to run again with Max as well and the last occasion wasn't just a one off.

Nicholai was pretty fit, being in the Danish Army. His best 5k time was in the 17 minute something region. Blooming quick. Anyway Daddy chatted lots with him even on the run. We got a good time in the 26 minutes this week, which considering the hills was a very pleasing time.

We stepped into Hampstead Heath village and went to a tea shop for ermm.. tea and toast, along with our two friends.

We said our goodbyes and caught a bus southbound and headed towards our start point, which was St Paul's cathedral. They're we had a spot of lunch and basked in the sunshine, before crossing the Millennium bridge over to Southwark. We passed the Globe and Golden Hinde and some small theatre which is older than the Globe. We toured around a busy Southwark Cathedral, then the highlight, Borough Market. Daddy treated us to a large cookie, and croissants. They were delicious. So much good food, hard to go wrong really. We stopped off at the George Inn close by which is the oldest Inn in London. Katie was checking the beer barrels.

We headed over London Bridge where we saw an interesting Pedi-Bus. About 10 people cycling on this platform to provide the energy to move the platform on. Genius idea. Looked like it was being used for hen/stag parties as most of the passengers were drinking! We ended the walk at Monument, then made the 19 stop journey along the District line back to Gunnersbury and home.

In the evening Mummy went out to Zizi's for a surprise dinner for Anna Strangle.

title.value: Walk 53: Shakespeare London. Hampstead Heath Park Run.

info.content:
Mummy's turn for Come Dine With Me. Started with tinned soup, spag boll, then the deal clincher, a sweetie pizza, where Mummy presented us with pizza dough which we had to flatten at the dinner table, then add the selection of chocolates, marshmallows and sweeties. Extra for marks for originality on the pudding. Marks off for tinned soup!

Sweetie Pizzas

We dropped Daddy off with James who along with other park runners were off to run in the inaugural Surrey half marathon. The course was basically a 'there and 'back' from the Spectrum to Woking town centre.

Surrey Half'ers

It was a hot day and Daddy had not done a lot of training, but still managed to do 2:13 hours, which was not too bad. It was pretty hilly as well. He got a lift home with Paula Fudge, an ex world record holder at 5k. It was interesting speaking to her about her career.

Meanwhile, the rest of us went to Fleet for Joshua Sanders, 3rd birthday party. It was nice to catch up.

title.value: Surrey Half Marathon, Joshua Sanders 3rd Birthday Party

info.content:
We decided to do the home parkrun today. Jasper Henderson was also doing it which meant only one thing. A race and a faster pace from Ben. We set off in the lead, Jasper caught up with 1km to go, thinking that'll be it for Ben. However, he upped the pace and shrugged Jasper off and finished in 25:39 minutes which smashed his old PB by 1 minute, 7 seconds. He was most proud and phoned Uncle Michael to tell him.

In the afternoon, mummy went to the Mall in Camberley to collect for Marie Curie cancer for an hour and a half. After which she went with us lot to Alice's birthday party at Cascades swimming pool near Gravesend. We had a good time, although inherited some bruises from the flumes!

Meanwhile daddy was preparing an epic meal of 3 courses. He knew the children were unlikely to go for the menu. However, he ploughed on. Starters was pineapple and strawberries. Main was a Jamie Oliver filo pie with spinach, cheese, nuts and various herbs, with a tomato salad and cucumber salad. The children barely touched this. Finally we ended with a very lemony, lemon drizzle cake.

During the meal we put forward our ideas for the summer holiday and voted two finalists. Ben's, Northern Ireland and Jessica's Scotland holidays were the winners. So they now have to cost it out and actually come up with an itinerary for the final vote.

title.value: Ben PB Parkrun, Marie Curie, Alice 7th Birthday, Daddy Come Dine With Me

info.content:
Daddy took Ben and Katie, along with the Fars and Richard to Wembley to watch a friendly international between England and Denmark. Of course Ben was supporting Denmark and Katie, who really couldn't care too much, was on the English side.

We took Richard and met with the Fars in Ruslip for a McDonalds dinner. The Fars were not too pleased with this. Farfar, boycotted the place and went elsewhere, whilst Farmor needed help order fast food!

We caught the tube and got off at Wembley Park and walked down Olympic way. There were thousands and thousands of people. We'd never seen so many. I guess that was the main reason for coming, was to experience such a large crowd. It was a very friendly and safe atmosphere.

We had seats right at the back of the stadium. No one sat behind us! Still we still had a reasonable view. There were 65,000 people there. The game was OK, enjoyed by the children especially when the Mexican wave started up.

The game ended with a late winner for England, making it a 1-0 scoreline. We had the long, busy walk back to the tube, and then a car journey ending at midnight back home. School in the morning.

Wembley

Daddy and Ben went to Wimbledon Common parkrun where Daddy met up with Max Dinning, a school friend from 26 years ago! Wow they had a lot to catch up on. Anyway, it was a very muddy run and was proceeded with a nice cup of tea and a catch up.

In the afternoon we all went out for a family walk starting at the air-force memorial in Englefield Green. It was very wet and the whole area had been flooded just two weeks before. We looked around the memorial and saw the surnames: Gay and Weston. I wonder if they are relatives of ours? We continued our walk which ended up over the Pleasure grounds. The return journey was quite eventful. We crossed some wet fields, that got more and more wet as we ventured. Soon the water got so high Daddy had to carry us one by one. Eventually the water got too high for Daddy, and he almost lost balance in the sinking mud when he had Katie on his shoulders. Not sure how they did not fall in. Anyway we had to leave Ben and Jessica around the corner whilst Daddy was ferrying KAtie across. All the girls were getting hysterical. They decided that Mummy and Katie should continue to the car, whilst the others could not continue and headed back to the pleasure grounds, via shinning a tree to overcome the barbed wire fence.

Airforce Memorial

Going down Coopers Hill

Puddles, lakes

After church we rushed over to Godstone Farm and joined Ma Ma, Pop Pop, Ellie, Lily, Joey, and Toby. We had a great time on the hill slide.

Train down the hill slide

Summer Teale came over for a sleepover with Katie. Surprisingly they didn't stay up too late. They played teenage mums! Daddy and Ben went and did the Alice Holt parkrun, whilst the rest of us played in the playground. We then went direct to Ikea in Southampton where mummy and daddy picked up a few supplies as well as ideas for when the extension gets put up.

We had a busy day. In the morning Daddy borrowed a high ladder and he went up and cleaned all the gutters and upstairs windows, whilst the rest of us went to church. Also all the fence panel that got blown over needed cleaning up.

Meanwhile Ben had an early meet at Farnborough Station as he went up with the cubs to the Outdoor Show at Excel, London. He had a great time. As well as handling a snake, he was raving about the stunt show and all the freebies he got. We love the Columbia Cub group. They're great.

Ben had a lucky escape as the rest of us continued on the Surrey Kids walk book, with an excursion from Pirbright to Fox Corner. Daddy's legs began to get pins and needles in the end so we had to rush home and feed him some sugar!!!

Ben handling a snake

Through Pirbright

title.value: Walk 51: Pirbright and Fox Corner. Cubs at Outdoor Show

info.content:
We went to the other side of Camberley and followed the Barossa Common walk from the walk. Ben was very happy and very grumpy all at the same time.

Happy Walkers!

Daddy and Ben went with the other Frimley Flyers over to Greenham Common for the Newbury Parkrun. It started sunny, then the heavens opened and the temperature dropped. The photographer saw Daddy's 50th badge and thought that he was 50 years old!!! Cheeky.

We rushed back and then went over to Alton for Joey's birthday party. He had invited 3 other mates and Ben over to Basingstoke Ten Pin bowling.

We rushed then to Poppy's party which was a swimming affair at Farnborough leisure centre.

title.value: 50th Parkrun, Joey's 9th Birthday Party, Poppy's 11th Birthday Party

info.content:
We had to call on Farfar to look after Jessica in the morning. Farfar read lots to Jess who has had her second time off school since Christmas. I hope she'll be OK.

In the evening was her Parent's Evening. Thankfully the teacher was pleased with her progress. Overall happy, attentive, lots of friends and either average or slightly above average in her subjects. Well done Jessa.
After church we went over to Windsor where we met with Uncle Steven and Eva for a swim and play on the flumes and wave machine.

Katie has now reached the age of what I'd call, adolescence. Physically changes can be noticed and emotionally. In the mornings she is not so good as she used to be. She is still as lovely as can be though

We went to Greenwich for a surprise trip around Greenwich as a 40th wedding anniversary celebration. We started by Wolfe's statue at the top of the hill, then made our way down into town where we had some lunch.

We had the usual race under the tunnel and caught a DLR and tube to North Greenwich where we tried out the cable cars.

Fly Emerites

Oaking about

Album Cover

title.value: Greenwich - Ma Ma and Pop Pop's 40th Wedding Anniversary

info.content:
Katie and Leah Rushforth have been selected to become house captains. As such Katie has had to make a speech to a quatre of the school. She, as well as the rest of us are most proud.

Katie sporting house captains badge

Ben spent the weekend away at cub camp, which is always very good for him, getting away from the parents! He absolutely loves playing games, building fires, tee pees and this time catapults. He was also invested.

Getting sworn in officially as a cub

After Daddy Parkrunned and lunch we went out to see where Daddy works in Eashing and played by the river. Jessica was not feeling too well. We stopped off on the way home at Elstead and played in the playground for half and hour or so.

In the evening Mummy and Daddy went to the Six Bells pub in Farnham to celebrate with the rest of the family Ma Ma and Pop Pop's 40th wedding anniversary.

title.value: Eashing, Ma Ma and Pop Pops 40th Anniversary Skittles Night

info.content:
Daddy and Ben took Uncle Michael and Joey to the London Motor Museum in Hayes. They had a great time looking at all the customized cars.

GT40

Del Boys

The purchase of 162 Frimley Green Road has not gone without incident. After a month in the house we receive a letter from the SRA to say that Ashworth Law, the firm who dealt with our house transaction, had been stopped from trading due to dishonesty claims. We thought we'd be OK because our sale went through a month previously and surely the contracts would have not been exchanged or completed. WRONG! It would appear that the money obtained from our house and the mortgage was used to buy the new house, no problem, however the solicitors failed to get around to paying off 42 Swordsmans Road. As a result, the new occupiers could not register with the Land Registry as our mortgage was still unpaid. Furthermore, the Stamp Duty of Â£8250 had not been paid off via the Inland Revenue. So not only did the money not get paid, but the contracts were never completed it would appear on the day! What a joke of a conveyancey system this country has. So we have been left with paying off two mortgages, been fined a Â£100 for late Stamp Duty payment and lobbing out Â£175 per hour for a new set of solicitors to complete the sale and purchase of the respective houses we own!

An intervening agent is assigned who acts similar to an administrator. They are the ones who freeze the accounts. Nothing comes in or out. They said it will be at least up till the late summer before any sort of resolution can be expected. Even then nothing is guaranteed. In the meanwhile we have filed for compensation via the SRA. In total we are currently Â£87,000 down.

Ashworth Law Article

title.value: Â£87,000 down after Solicitor is stopped by SRA for dishonesty

info.content:
Daddy was pleasantly surprised to hear that he'd done well at work and was given a Â£100 to spend on a meal for the family as a reward! Woo Hoo. Where to go? Well, we chose somewhere a little different, Buona Sera At The Jam, Kings Road, Chelsea for a spot of lunch, after parkrun of course.

It was a little different as it was the bunk bed equivalent of restauranting. We were led to our table via a small ladder, in this small, narrow eatery. We had three courses and drinks which and a good chat with the restaurant owner who we didn't think was the full ticket.

Happy Eaters

Climb to the table

We then caught a bus across London to St John Soames museum in Lincoln Inn Fields, Holborn. We left Mumma to queue whilst the rest of us played 40-40. The museum was different as it had a collection of John Soames artefacts when he travelled around the world. The house was certainly different. Not really for children, but a good experience.

title.value: Buona Sera At The Jam and Sir John Soames Museum
